S-X2
2053. Woodward, John
Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: JOHN WOODWARD
Present Address: HINCHCLIFFE SASK
Pioneer Address: 1905
Year you came to Saskatchewan:

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1924, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting about back and forth? 12

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 5

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? once a month, in the winter not so often

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? frequently

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? mostly without

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? sometimes in the morning also after dinner

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? oh yes

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) do we just sit down after conversation and dined.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? tea, sometimes coffee, always coffee among the Scandinavian doughnuts

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? some times

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? a few times, we had building bees, and also to put in crop or take it off for sick neighbors

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. Several times a year

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

many, sometimes during storms there would be as many as 12 or 14 sleeping on the floor covered by horse blankets, all beds being full. Dances were very popular, music being local, wonderful, varied, but everyone enjoyed it the rhythm being good.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

No they were not, the settlers grew older, their children grew up and demanded modern dance music. They got it.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?

Quite informal, messages were delivered by the scholars and mostly the gatherings were organized that way.
PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting about back and forth?
   How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? (Was it once a month, or the other days?)

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Frequently

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Mostly without

That idea of the day did you go - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Sometimes in the morning also after dinner

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes, sometimes coffee always offered

Did we ever sit down for conversation and dined? Some times

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Several times a year

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such projects? Sometimes

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, listing dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst moving? Sometimes during storms there would be as many as 10 or 14 standing on the floor covered by horse blankets.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? And they would meet at some house. They got it.

And mostly the gatherings were organized that way.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

Much use was made of the schoolhouse for social activities and the grounds, which we kept well mowed, were used for sports events mostly followed by a social evening and a dance.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

90% of it, we as yet, had no railroads and were somewhat isolated until 1917 when the Thunder Hill branch was built. CNR, then Sturgis & Princeville came into being, then we could trade at these villages and cut out the long trips about 1935.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? Lumber. How large was it? 22 x 60

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Community effort, labour, Coop-organized under Bank coop - organization.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Hamlet & Country, 1 mile south of school.

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.)?

We used the hall for social gatherings except on sport days when we used the school grounds, which were well kept all the time.

Now the Sturgis Unit built us a new school in the Hamlet. The old log school still stands.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

Usually.

How were babies and small children provided for? Wrapped up and put to sleep on school desks, sometimes, their mothers were very ingenious in that respect.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? We built a log barn 22' x 22'.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Whist was quite popular, and other card games.

Was there card playing for a prize? Often.

What dances were popular? Waltz, Schottische, square Dances, two step and others including step dancing, mostly by ontario.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. Very little in the early years people were hungry for social contacts.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

No, not all played cards, but non players were quite tolerant about the matter and again social contacts were important and were enjoyed.
2. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, etc., if you have any idea, (include also the school questionnaires). Give dates.

For social activities, and the grounds, which we used, were movies, were used mostly for socializing and dancing.

90% of the use was made of the school house, and within the school district? Describe.

Was there any special material used in the school house? If so, describe.

What was your first community hall built? Out of the long range?

What was its name? 1935

Who built it? The community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Organization, etc.?

Community effort, labor, cost organized under county, township, or was it a country hall? 5:00 Shows, etc.

Was it built by the village or town, or was it a county hall? 5:00 Shows, etc.

Was the school used for other purposes? For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come into the hall in town for other functions, etc.? Or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?

We used the hall for social gatherings except on short days when we used the school grounds, which were well kept all the time.

Show the story, but build us a new school in the hamlet.

When parties, dances, etc., were held in houses, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 6, 7, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for? Usually wrapped up and put to sleep on school chairs, sometimes their mother's knee.

What card games were popular in the early days?

What card playing was popular? Of an

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

In the early years people went hungry in community gatherings! Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or far off?

Not all played cards, but own players were quite tolerant about the matter and again seeing off contacts were important and were enjoyed.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? Very little indeed, practically everyone was financially embarrassed in the early years. The few who were not, were good mannered.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Rarely about it.

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

They were mostly indifferently supported.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Visiting and social life fell off somewhat about 1915 during the first great war. About 30 of our young men enlisted and 4 failed to come back. After the war our people had prospered somewhat and social organizations and meetings, life while still carried on was not so spontaneous as in pre-war times.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Saskatchewan Grain Growers

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

Date about 1910

We were out of funds through expense of clearing land, etc., this district was nearly all bush land, after hauling grain 47 miles to Canada and obtaining only $8 to $5 per bushel.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers Local in your community? Yes

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

A neighboring homesteader from the Pleasanton District came up and we called a meeting in the schoolhouse.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? 90%

How many women belonged? None

How often did it meet? About 6 or 8 times a year

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

We talked organization to others, we cooperated in hauling grain on the long haul, we paid our dues to Central Regina, sent delegates to various places, one each to organization of the Sask Coop Elevator Co., also to the Convention when the Coop and the Pool were amalgamated and generally supported all coop movements since.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?

No, we had a U. Church ladies club which we still have.

When was it organized? 1915

Approximately how many women belonged to it? 30

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

They have organized many social gatherings in the past, helpful support to many worthy causes, and in many other respects have been a decided factor in local social activities.
12. What attempts at formality, or "manners," do you remember in small towns such as those in which you lived? How did people behave toward each other?

13. Were there any particular customs or traditions that stood out in your community?

Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who was engaged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

Soccer Football club which organized Sports and games including matches with neighboring School districts; we had several players of real merit, from not only Britain but Denmark also, one of the Danes is manager and owner of the Creamery and Dairy Products at the PA.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

Concerts, taking the hat around, but mostly paying our own expenses, but we attracted 7 or 800 people who came to see the games.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

The Schoolhouse

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.?

No Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

It must be stated that our early settlers who came from Europe were people of a good order of intelligence, with fair educations. So we did not lack for subjects of discussion. There was no difficulty in obtaining good literature.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

mostly Biblical Pictures

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (jump rope, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   Football, tag wrestling, jambing.

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.
Children, older boys football before snow came.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.
   The young got plenty of time to play, to trap, M.Rats were also set for pocket money.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.
   They built igloos, skied, skated, hunted a little.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.
   June 1st 1905

26. Who organized it?
   Mr. Wright & myself at the Ranch.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?
   There was no such organization.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? Yes
   If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?
   We, Mr. Wright & I fixed up pole vaulting jumps, high jump, long jump, 100 yard dash, using the throwing stick.

There were only 5 settlers in the district.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?
   We all fed at Mr. Wright's Table which was a most hospitable one.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?
   Roast Beef, F.W. killed a steer, pies, cakes, cookies and all the trimmings.

Mr. Wright's daughter looked after the cooking, and believe now Mrs. Tom Reinders, a neighboring rancher, was her husband.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
   2 o'clock to 7 o'clock.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Face," "Leap," "Wuthering" or others, checkers or other games? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent names connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

The quiet places, streets, schools, limited a little.

PIONEER AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it? Mr. Wright, myself at the nearest school.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization?

There were only 5 settlers on the dig site but there were many families, perhaps 10.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? Yes

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

There were only 5 settlers on the dig site but there were many families, perhaps 10.

30. What arrangements were made for eating? Was there a general lunch, or did we all feed at Mr. Wright's Table which was a great hospitality one, or did everyone cook their own meal?

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Boast Beef, F.W. Miller, a star, nice, tasty, cooked and ate the homemaking and believe you please, from Religion, Mrs. Husbands, a neighboring rancher, Mrs. Husbands.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

This was the first picnic organized North of T-35-R-5-W 2nd. I believe Mr. Jack Shoafelt distinguished himself by clipping off the head of a fine Plymouth Rocker with his first throw of the Indian throwing stick, which worked when thrown by an expert, something like an Australian boomerang.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

Lots of picnics were held in the summer down at Squaw Lake, 2 1/2 miles south, mostly on Sundays. The hamlet of Lady Lake was named after this lake we submitted the name to the R.R. people but they finally compromised with Lady Lake. The legend of a young Cree girl was disappointed in love about 70-80 years ago, and swam out to an island in the lake and hid there afterwards disappearing.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

Squaw Lake is a beautiful gem surrounded by hills and spruce bluffs and was a favorite as a summer camping ground by the local Crees, after the tragedy occurred they abandoned the summer camp there, family quarrels over the incident split the Cree society.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly and young people).

Soccer Football, Pole vaulting, Jumping, Speed, Dash, and other races, Horse racing, Pole wrestling, Hop skip jump, long jump, egg racing, Backball.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Soccer Football, Base Ball

What year? 1906 How long did it continue? 46 years

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

Poveshulle organized football team in 1910 and Ball Team and played with Edmonton, some games came into Poveshulle and were good soccer players of them is now the Creamery Manager. Owner of the Creamery teams also came in from what is now the Sturgis District.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

About 1930 Hockey and skating.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
This was the first picnic organized North of 7-35 R.W. 24. I believe my name should be written in the place of Mr. Sherrill's name.

Describe any features of this picnic which you remember at this time.

33. Describe any different kinds of plants which you know of in the area (family, species, etc.)?

34. Tell about any differences in numbers attending activities such as the annual community picnic, school or Sunday school, family picnics, etc.?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger games, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.)

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1906

Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?

J. Woodworth

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? A group of us myself, Geo. W. H., E. Louie, F.W. Wright, G.T.B. Benson, E. Weeks.

Then was the sports day usually held? (What month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st.)

July.

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names and dates.

No, we were too isolated.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

Encyclopedia, Mining Engineering, obtained a then 3rd class Certificate at Sheffield University, Scott Books, 3 good Horticultural works, History of Trade Unionism, was active in mining organizations, The Vegetable World, Handbook, Western Canadian Law, 1917.

History of the Holy Bible, 1816.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

The Bible, mostly popular Novels.

History a few books on Science, a few.

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? Some, I had to be careful, I learned a lot of the way of Wakefield to a neighbor before back with the help of my great-grandfather, John Bram, was on it.

Can you buy many books after you came west? (Give details)

Some fodder & pasture plants, Geo. H. Clothe B.S.A. for being careful to follow such matters as Dr. Thompson's articles, somewhat divergent views from publications and their meanings and the somewhat divergent views from publications and their meanings and the somewhat divergent views from publications and their meanings.

45. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

Canada Year Book 45 years.

46. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

A little, some of the scholars & some of their fathers & mothers borrowed, intermittently.

47. Was there a school library? Yes. When was it begun? 1912.

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

Some.

48. Did parents ever use their children's school texts as additional reading material?

I suppose so.

School Library before mentioned

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   Winnipeg Free Press, too busy for any other reading. When the Farm Papers began to be published, such as the Grain Growers Guide, Farmers Advocate, most of the Settlers subscribed.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others. They never were stopped.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? No
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
   Everything I have before mentioned, and others such as family school books, dating back to the 60 and 70's, and the 80's. Of the 19th century, for instance my grand uncles' copy of the Daily Middle Class School, &c., also my father's technical works; he was a sculptor, a book on money theory, Rev. E. Gurney.

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. No, I knew where to obtain them.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Only the school library.

When was it started? 1912

Is it still in existence? Yes

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contained, how many people used it, who was its librarian, what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

School library before mentioned

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? None

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions. They were varied.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Yes

54. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.

To obtain them...
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? A wife and three children.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Violins, one old organ, somewhat battered, Mrs. Usher owned it, no cornet, banjo, accordion, and Mr. Truax, an American who really was an artist on them, but you cannot use the bones at a church service.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them. I cannot play a note.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

Very much so, my daughters sang at school and church gatherings. My youngest son had a little band, our concerts were good, we were fortunate to have School Teachers most of them were in the community! (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

Yes, we had some good voices, mostly settlers from Britain and in the early years our schoolhouse used to be crowded to the door on concert nights.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

We were still influenced by the music left over from the Boer War, Goodbye Dolly Mule leave you tethered, etc., and from the Russo-Japanese War, Farewell little old Ban. We in the community then supported the boys as against In our own home we had a background the Russians of Gilbert & Sullivan and La Corte, also the choral music of England's Midland Counties.

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

Some Americans and Ontarians tried it, but were mostly received in a respectful, if deaf silence.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

No, I was never anything of a caricaturist, unless some of these comments may be construed as such.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes. When was it started? 1900.

Who started it? The older boys. How long did it continue? Intermittently, ever since.

How many were in it? 6-0-28

Who was bandmaster? Mr. Usher.

What instruments were included? Violins, organ, flute, cornet, banjo, bones, triangle, clarinet—a fine combination, but not at all bad.

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

When the boys got older they organized a creditable Dance Orchestra which lasted until quite recently and were the best dance orchestra in this part of the Province. My youngest son Harry Woodward was the leader, James Lobbie, late Editor of the Sturgis Review, was a member of it.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? We were still influenced by the music left over from the Boer War, Goodbye Dolly, I must leave you, Tipperary, etc., and from the Russo-Japanese War, Farewell little old Ban. We in the community then supported the boys against the Russians, in our own home we had a backdrop of the Russian ballet of Gilbert & Sullivan and Lady Conde, also the choral music of England's Midland Counties.

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain. Some Americans & Ontarians tried it, but were mostly received in a respectful, if deep silence.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain. No, I was never anything of a caricaturist, unless some of these comments may be construed as such.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes. When was it started? 1904-1905. Who started it? The older boys. How long did it continue? Intermittently ever since.

How many were in it? 6-8. Who was bandmaster? Mr. Usher.

What instruments were included? Violins, organ, flute, cornet, Banjo, bones, triangle, clarinet—a fine combination, but not at all good.

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for. When the boys got older they organized a creditable dance orchestra which lasted until quite recently and were the best dance orchestra in this part of the province. My youngest son Harry Woodward was the leader, James Tobin, late Editor of the Sturgis Review, was a member of it.
